title: Understanding VO2 Max
content: The case study of an individual with a high VO2 Max score is discussed. VO2 Max is a measure of the maximum volume of oxygen that an athlete can use. It is measured in milliliters per kilogram per minute. The individual in the case study had a VO2 Max score of 96.7 at the age of 18, the highest recorded score in human history. However, despite his high VO2 Max, his performance as a cyclist did not correlate perfectly with his score. This raises questions about the relationship between VO2 Max and athletic performance.

title: Efficiency in Athletic Performance
content: The efficiency of an athlete is discussed. Efficiency in this context refers to how much input (oxygen) is needed to maintain a given pace. The case study individual was most efficient when he was untrained, and his efficiency decreased as he trained more. This suggests that there may be an inverse relationship between VO2 Max and efficiency, meaning that as an athlete's VO2 Max increases, their efficiency may decrease. However, there is still no consensus on this.

title: VO2 Max and Economy in Elite Athletes
content: If you measure the VO2 max of a group of elite athletes, you tend to see an inverse relationship. The athletes with the highest VO2 max tend to have slightly lower, slightly worse economies. Those with the best economy, tend to have slightly worse VO2 max. There are two possible explanations for this phenomenon. The first is that if you happen to have a very high VO2 max, you're not likely to also have the best possible economy. The second possibility is that there's a trade-off. If you're optimizing one physiological parameter it may come at the cost of the other physiological parameter.

title: Training Impact on VO2 Max and Economy
content: The training done by athletes can have a significant impact on their VO2 max and economy. Training that requires very high VO2 max level outputs can cause your metabolism and cells to prioritize high output over efficiency. Over time, this can lead to a loss of efficiency and a slight penalty for optimizing your training for VO2 max. This is supported by a study of athlete Oskar Svensson, whose training increased his VO2 max but may have been detrimental to his economy at a metabolic level.

title: Training Strategy and Efficiency
content: The question worth considering is what would have happened if you took an athlete's genetic gift of an engine and instead of maximizing on VO2 max, you train him in a way that puts more effort into zone 2 (right at lactate of 2.0). This could potentially lead to a lower VO2 max, but a better overall performance. This observation agrees with the prevailing wisdom among endurance athletes that about 80% of your training should be easy, conversational pace (i.e., zone 2).
